original_query: What are the production challenges and solutions associated with the large-scale manufacturing of recombinant antibodies?
input: are production challenges solutions associated large scale manufacturing of recombinant antibodies

sections.title: Introduction/Background
sections.tldr: Recombinant antibodies represent a multi-billion dollar market with growing demand, particularly for monoclonal antibodies (mAbs). The manufacturing of these complex biologics presents unique challenges due to their molecular complexity, production requirements, and the need for cost reduction to remain competitive. (9 sources)
sections.text:
Recombinant antibodies, particularly monoclonal antibodies (mAbs), have emerged as critical therapeutic agents since the approval of the first licensed mAb in 1986, evolving into a substantial multi-billion dollar market <Paper corpusId="267845612" paperTitle="(Sewell et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. The market valuation is expected to grow dramatically from $115.2 billion in 2018 to approximately $300 billion by 2025, highlighting the increasing importance of these biopharmaceuticals <Paper corpusId="265464221" paperTitle="(Olin et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. This rapid growth has driven manufacturers to develop innovative solutions for large-scale production to meet expanding clinical and commercial demands <Paper corpusId="43129756" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>.

Unlike small molecule drugs, biologics such as mAbs are large, complex molecules produced in living systems including bacteria and mammalian cells. Their molecular structure consists of over 1300 amino acids arranged in various subunits, with molecular weights of approximately 150,000 daltons and numerous post-translational modifications <Paper corpusId="52079235" paperTitle="(Melsheimer et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. This complexity introduces significant variability in the production process, requiring careful control of manufacturing conditions.

As production demands increase, manufacturers face the challenge of purification on larger scales, with some batches reaching up to 100 kg, necessitating innovative purification methodologies <Paper corpusId="13884331" paperTitle="(Murphy et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. To address these challenges, platform manufacturing processes have emerged for monoclonal antibodies, standardizing unit operations and reducing development time for new molecules <Paper corpusId="232039925" paperTitle="(Crowell et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. However, more diverse biopharmaceutical pipelines often require unique production and purification processes, adding complexity to large-scale manufacturing.

The industry has responded by building large-scale manufacturing facilities with multiple 10,000 L or larger cell culture bioreactors <Paper corpusId="43129756" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. Both traditional fed-batch cell cultivation for high-quality mAbs and continuous bioprocessing employing perfusion bioreactors for challenging molecules are utilized to optimize production <Paper corpusId="267845612" paperTitle="(Sewell et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. The latter approach has proven beneficial for products like infliximab (Remicade) that exhibited particularly low titers <Paper corpusId="267845612" paperTitle="(Sewell et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="25001402" paperTitle="(Kelley, 2009)" isShortName></Paper>.

Cost considerations are also driving manufacturing innovations, with pressure to reduce the cost of goods (CoGs) to remain competitive and to make therapies more affordable <Paper corpusId="265464221" paperTitle="(Olin et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. This is particularly important for diagnostic applications, where there is demand for rapid tests costing less than $1, making cost-effective production methods like those using Escherichia coli vital <Paper corpusId="237387732" paperTitle="(Huleani et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, the development of antibody combination therapeutics (ACTs) for complex diseases presents unique manufacturing challenges due to the cost-prohibitive nature of independently manufacturing and mixing multiple monoclonal antibodies <Paper corpusId="24135749" paperTitle="(Wilmes et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

paper.title: Enhancing the functionality of a microscale bioreactor system as an industrial process development tool for mammalian perfusion culture

snippets: Since the approval of the first licensed monoclonal antibody (mAb) in 1986, the demand for mAbs as therapeutic agents has developed into a multi-billion dollar per year market (Liu, 2014). Process optimization for large manufacturing facilities based on fed-batch cell cultivation allowed sufficient productivity of high product quality mAbs (Birch et al., 2006). On the other hand, continuous bioprocessing employing perfusion bioreactors is utilized in the production of molecules that proved to be challenging to express or recover. The low bioreactor residence times associated with continuous production systems, and the continuous removal of potentially toxic by-products, allows cells to reach high cell concentrations and improves total functional production. Currently, continuous production is widely accepted as beneficial for the manufacture of products such as infliximab (Remicade) that exhibited particularly low titres (B. (Kelley, 2009), and haemoglobin factor VIII (ReFacto), which required minimal residence times in the bioreactor (Vogel et al., 2012).

paper.title: An automated high inoculation density fed‐batch bioreactor, enabled through N‐1 perfusion, accommodates clonal diversity and doubles titers

snippets: As the monoclonal antibody market valuation is ballooning rapidly, with an increase from $115.2 billion in 2018 to an expected $300 billion by 2025. 1 As the commercial pipeline of these proteins expands, a large challenge manufacturers face is dramatically reducing the cost of goods (CoGs) to remain competitive in the growing manufacturing space while also promoting democratization of therapies through reduction of cost to the customer. One effective method to reduce CoGs for biotherapeutics manufacturing is increasing the productivity in the production bioreactor, which increases total product yield without an increase in bioreactor resources.

paper.title: Cell culture processes for monoclonal antibody production

snippets: With the increasing number of protein therapeutic candidates, especially monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) entering various stages of development, biopharmaceutical companies are increasingly looking at innovative solutions to deliver this pipeline. For antibody manufacturing process development, maintaining desired quality attributes while reducing time to market, maintaining cost effectiveness, and providing manufacturing flexibility are key issues in today's competitive market, where several companies are often working on therapies for similar targets and clinical indications. Since antibody therapies may require large doses over a long period of time, manufacturing capacity becomes an issue because the drug substance must be produced in large quantities with cost and time efficiency to meet clinical requirements and pave the way toward commercialization. In response to the strong demand, many companies have built large scale manufacturing plants containing multiple 10,000 L or larger cell culture bioreactors.

paper.title: Ensuring Product Quality, Consistency and Patient Supply over Time for a Large-Volume Biologic: Experience with Remicade®

snippets:
In this summary, we review the challenges associated with manufacturing large-volume biologics and the measures needed to ensure high-quality, long-term consistency and adequate supply by presentation of the example of one of the most widely used biologics today, Remicade.

In contrast to small molecule drugs, which have defined chemical structures and are produced by predictable chemical synthesis, biologics are large molecules produced in living systems (e.g., bacteria, mammalian cells) grown in complex cell culture media. By their very nature, biologics are subject to structural variability, which may alter their properties (e.g., binding, solubility, potency and immunogenicity), and consequently their safety and efficacy in clinical practice. In general, the larger the molecule, the greater the potential variability. Monoclonal antibodies such as Remicade are among the largest, most complex biologics, containing 1300 + amino acids arranged in various subunits, with molecular weights of approximately 150,000 daltons. These antibodies undergo many post-translational modifications and consist of various isoforms containing heterogeneous glycosylation patterns. The degree of potential variability with monoclonal antibodies is considerable.

Moreover, the living systems producing biologics are sensitive to the environment. Even subtle variations in the manufacturing process, such as changes in the cell culture media, pH or temperature, can lead to additional variability in the product. Raw materials used in production, such as in drug product excipients (e.g., sucrose or polysorbate 80) and in cell culture media (e.g., trace metals), are themselves additional potential sources of variability. The manufacturer must identify, understand and measure these sources of variability and then develop a manufacturing process that can produce drug with variability kept within acceptable levels. It is essential that this process, once developed, remains stable. However, over time, it will likely be expanded or updated, which presents an additional challenge. Given the sensitivity of the biologic to its environment, the manufacturer must ensure that process changes do not alter any of its key attributes. The central challenge, therefore, to producing biologics is to do so consistently over long periods of time at an industrial scale.

paper.title: Technology advancements in antibody purification

snippets: The current capabilities of antibody production by recombinant techniques has increased the need for purification on a larger scale (up to 100 kg batches), (Thömmes et al., 2007) thus requiring innovative purification methodologies.

paper.title: Development of a platform process for the production and purification of single‐domain antibodies

snippets: For some classes of molecules, such as monoclonal antibodies, platform manufacturing processes have emerged to reduce the time and effort required to develop a manufacturing process for a new molecule. In a platform process, the overall unit operations and order of these operations are standardized. Each new product, therefore, requires only minimal optimization of these steps. Biopharmaceutical pipelines are becoming more diverse, however, and other classes of biologics generally require unique production and purification processes, even for similar molecules (Morrison, 2020). Developing processes for these nonplatform biologics requires significant time and effort, limiting the number of molecules that can be manufactured for nonclinical or clinical use.

paper.title: Industrialization of mAb production technology: The bioprocessing industry at a crossroads

snippets: The rapid growth in product demand for mAbs triggered parallel efforts to increase production capacity through construction of large bulk manufacturing plants as well as improvements in cell culture processes to raise product titers. This combination has led to an excess of manufacturing capacity, and together with improvements in conventional purification technologies, promises nearly unlimited production capacity in the foreseeable future. The increase in titers has also led to a marked reduction in production costs, which could then become a relatively small fraction of sales price for future products which are sold at prices at or near current levels.

paper.title: Escherichia coli as an antibody expression host for the production of diagnostic proteins: significance and expression

snippets: There is intense pressure for more accurate and less expensive rapid diagnostic tests, with a value preferably <$1. Thus, the large-scale cost-effective production of recombinant antibodies is vital. The importance of Escherichia coli toward the production of inexpensive rapid tests will be explained in this review paper. Details about the different strains of E. coli, the strategies used for the insertion and the expression of recombinant proteins, and the challenges that still exist are provided.

paper.title: Non-viral adeno-associated virus-based platform for stable expression of antibody combination therapeutics

snippets: Antibody combination therapeutics (ACTs) are polyvalent biopharmaceuticals that are uniquely suited for the control of complex diseases, including antibiotic resistant infectious diseases, autoimmune disorders and cancers. However, ACTs also represent a distinct manufacturing challenge because the independent manufacture and subsequent mixing of monoclonal antibodies quickly becomes cost prohibitive as more complex mixtures are envisioned.

sections.title: Current Manufacturing Approaches
sections.tldr: Current manufacturing approaches for recombinant antibodies primarily rely on mammalian cell systems, especially Chinese Hamster Ovary (CHO) cells, with both fed-batch and continuous production methods. Manufacturing capacity has evolved from traditional stainless-steel bioreactors to include single-use systems and continuous bioprocessing, with technological improvements driving dramatic increases in production yields. (9 sources)
sections.text:
Mammalian cell culture, particularly Chinese Hamster Ovary (CHO) cells, dominates commercial recombinant antibody production due to their ability to produce proteins with human-like post-translational modifications and adaptability to serum-free media <Paper corpusId="52982930" paperTitle="(Velugula-Yellela et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. These production systems have undergone remarkable evolution, with average yields for commercial monoclonal antibody (mAb) production typically reaching 5-6 g/L and continuing to rise <Paper corpusId="52982930" paperTitle="(Velugula-Yellela et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. Even more impressively, industrial IgG production levels often exceed 12 g/L, with the highest reported titer reaching 27 g/L in the human embryonic retinal cell line Per.C6 <Paper corpusId="8559221" paperTitle="(Frenzel et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>.

The manufacturing landscape currently employs two primary approaches: fed-batch cultivation and continuous bioprocessing. Fed-batch cultures have traditionally been used to produce high quantities of biotherapeutics, particularly monoclonal antibodies <Paper corpusId="235270874" paperTitle="(Donaldson et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. However, for next-generation biotherapeutics such as bi-specific antibodies and fusion proteins that are difficult to express using standard fed-batch processes, manufacturers are increasingly adopting strategies that decouple cell growth from production <Paper corpusId="235270874" paperTitle="(Donaldson et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach allows cellular resources to be more efficiently directed toward either growth or production, enhancing the production of difficult-to-express proteins <Paper corpusId="235270874" paperTitle="(Donaldson et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

In parallel, continuous bioprocessing employing perfusion bioreactors has gained traction for molecules that prove challenging to express or recover <Paper corpusId="267845612" paperTitle="(Sewell et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. The shorter bioreactor residence times and continuous removal of potentially toxic by-products enable cells to reach higher concentrations and improve total functional production <Paper corpusId="267845612" paperTitle="(Sewell et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach has proven particularly beneficial for products like infliximab (Remicade) that exhibited low titers <Paper corpusId="267845612" paperTitle="(Sewell et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="25001402" paperTitle="(Kelley, 2009)" isShortName></Paper>.

The physical infrastructure of manufacturing has also evolved. Historically, stainless-steel bioreactors were used for large-scale production, but single-use bioreactors have become increasingly common <Paper corpusId="235823004" paperTitle="(Whaley et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. The shift toward single-use systems offers advantages including reduced turnaround time between manufacturing runs, lower upfront investment costs, and decreased operational and maintenance expenses <Paper corpusId="235823004" paperTitle="(Whaley et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Multiple single-use bioreactors can be deployed to produce mAbs at scale with significantly lower capital investment, enabling the development of global production facilities through distributed manufacturing <Paper corpusId="235823004" paperTitle="(Whaley et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

The industry is also seeing a gradual transition from batch to continuous processing, driven by increasing demand, cost reduction pressures, requirements for consistent quality, and the need for higher productivity <Paper corpusId="52883669" paperTitle="(Cankorur-Cetinkaya et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. Integrated continuous biomanufacturing processes offer advantages including faster production, lower costs, more consistent processing, and potentially greater product quality <Paper corpusId="235823004" paperTitle="(Whaley et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Economic analyses suggest that continuous biomanufacturing coupled with continuous chromatographic processes can reduce costs by 55% compared to conventional batch processing when considering both capital and operating expenses <Paper corpusId="235823004" paperTitle="(Whaley et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

For specialized applications like recombinant polyclonal hyperimmune globulins, which consist of thousands of different antibodies, researchers have demonstrated that existing infrastructure for mAb manufacturing can be repurposed without constructing new facilities <Paper corpusId="250712798" paperTitle="(Mizrahi et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. This adaptability highlights the flexibility of current manufacturing approaches to accommodate novel therapeutic modalities.

The dramatic improvements in antibody production have been achieved through a combination of cell engineering, process optimization, and advancements in media formulation and feeding strategies <Paper corpusId="52982930" paperTitle="(Velugula-Yellela et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. Producer cell lines have been genetically engineered to improve product homogeneity, metabolism, reduce apoptosis, and enable inducible cell cycle arrest, allowing for extended production periods of almost three weeks while maintaining high cell viability and densities <Paper corpusId="8559221" paperTitle="(Frenzel et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>.

While mammalian cell systems dominate, bacterial expression systems remain relevant for simpler antibody fragments due to their low cost and high yield capabilities <Paper corpusId="256154128" paperTitle="(Pirkalkhoran et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. However, bacteria cannot perform post-translational modifications like glycosylation, which limits their application for full-length antibodies <Paper corpusId="256154128" paperTitle="(Pirkalkhoran et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

paper.title: Use of High-Throughput Automated Microbioreactor System for Production of Model IgG1 in CHO Cells

snippets:
Most of the recombinant protein production processes employ Chinese Hamster Ovary (CHO) cells for the ease with which they can be adapted to serum free media, their ability to produce proteins with similar post-translational modifications to that of an innate human protein and their dependability as host cells (Jayapal et al., 2007)(Velugula-Yellela et al., 2017) .

Demand is growing to deliver product faster, and for larger patient populations with consistent quality

Average yields for modern commercial mAb production lines are typically in the range of 5-6 g/L and continue to rise (Jayapal et al., 2007) . In part, this has been accomplished through CHO cell engineering and improved production line screening using high-throughput bioreactors (Kondragunta et al., 2010) . However, most increases in protein production have been attributed to process improvements, including advancements in media optimization, cell culture conditions, and enhanced feeding strategies (Foltz et al., 2013)(Altamirano et al., 2000)(Selvarasu et al., 2012) . Nutrient supplementation is essential not only for proper cell growth but also for efficient production of high quality protein. Furthermore, cells require the stoichiometric addition of specific nutrients, requiring additional understanding for feeding strategy optimization (Velugula-Yellela et al., 2017)11 .

paper.title: Expression of Recombinant Antibodies

snippets: Today, industrial IgG production levels often exceed 12 g/L as the result of a steadily ongoing progress in mammalian cell culture technology, which is mainly due to improved high producer cell lines, optimized production media, and prolonged production processes at high-cell densities. The highest reported IgG production titer we found was obtained in the human embryonic retinal cell line Per.C6 [Crucell, Leiden, Netherlands, (Jones et al., 2003)] with 27 g/L. Generally, the productivity of recombinant mammalian cell lines increased from initially 10 pg antibody per cell per day (pcd) in 1986 to about 90 pcd in 2004. Today, the antibody production levels only rarely exceed 100 pcd because higher cellular productivity usually corresponds to lower maximum cell densities in the production process. Producer cell lines have also been genetically engineered regarding product homogeneity, improved metabolism, reduced apoptosis, and inducible cell cycle arrest (Butler, 2005)(Fussenegger et al., 1998) which allows prolonged production times for almost 3 weeks at high-cell viability and cell densities.

paper.title: Decoupling Growth and Protein Production in CHO Cells: A Targeted Approach

snippets: Fed-batch cultures of Chinese Hamster Ovary cells have been used to produce high quantities of biotherapeutics, particularly monoclonal antibodies. However, a growing number of next-generation biotherapeutics, such as bi-specific antibodies and fusion proteins, are difficult to express using standard fed-batch processes. Decoupling cell growth and biotherapeutic production is becoming an increasingly desired strategy for the biomanufacturing industry, especially for difficult-to-express products. Cells are grown to a high cell density in the absence of recombinant protein production (the growth phase), then expression of the recombinant protein is induced and cell proliferation halted (the production phase), usually by combining an inducible gene expression system with a proliferation control strategy. Separating the growth and production phases allows cell resources to be more efficiently directed toward either growth or production, improving growth characteristics and enhancing the production of difficult to express proteins.

Process optimization for large manufacturing facilities based on fed-batch cell cultivation allowed sufficient productivity of high product quality mAbs (Birch et al., 2006). On the other hand, continuous bioprocessing employing perfusion bioreactors is utilized in the production of molecules that proved to be challenging to express or recover. The low bioreactor residence times associated with continuous production systems, and the continuous removal of potentially toxic by-products, allows cells to reach high cell concentrations and improves total functional production. Currently, continuous production is widely accepted as beneficial for the manufacture of products such as infliximab (Remicade) that exhibited particularly low titres (B. (Kelley, 2009), and haemoglobin factor VIII (ReFacto), which required minimal residence times in the bioreactor (Vogel et al., 2012).

paper.title: Industrialization of mAb production technology: The bioprocessing industry at a crossroads

snippets: The rapid growth in product demand for mAbs triggered parallel efforts to increase production capacity through construction of large bulk manufacturing plants as well as improvements in cell culture processes to raise product titers. This combination has led to an excess of manufacturing capacity, and together with improvements in conventional purification technologies, promises nearly unlimited production capacity in the foreseeable future. The increase in titers has also led to a marked reduction in production costs, which could then become a relatively small fraction of sales price for future products which are sold at prices at or near current levels.

paper.title: Emerging antibody-based products for infectious diseases: Planning for metric ton manufacturing

snippets: Currently, most commercial mAbs are produced in mammalian cells (e.g. CHO, NS0) engineered to secrete large quantities of antibodies (typically in the 1-10 gram/liter range). Stainlesssteel bioreactors have historically been used for large-scale production, though single-use bioreactors have become more common in recent years due to the reduced turnaround time between manufacturing runs (clean-up operations are quicker) and reduced costs with respect to upfront investment as well as ongoing operational/maintenance expenses. Manufacturers specializing in one product generally tend to use stainlesssteel bioreactors, while single-use bioreactors are often used by contract manufacturers who produce a variety of different products. Setting up new manufacturing capacity has a significant lead time; modular platforms are being completed within 18 months while traditional fixed facilities can require several years. Multiple single-use bioreactors can be used to produce mAbs at scale and require significantly lower capital investment to construct. This technology has enabled the development of global mAb production facilities via distributed manufacturing. Integrated continuous biomanufacturing processes are also faster and cheaper and may offer more consistent processing and greater product quality. Economic analyses of continuous biomanufacturing coupled with continuous chromatographic processes (referred to as integrated continuous processing) can reduce costs by 55% compared to conventional batch processing, when both capital and operating expenses are considered.

paper.title: Process development for the continuous production of heterologous proteins by the industrial yeast, Komagataella phaffii

snippets: The ever-increasing demand for therapeutic antibodies may force many companies to change from batch processing to continuous production, because traditional fed-batch manufacturing cannot generate the huge quantities of r-proteins required without huge capital investments in a new plant (Warikoo et al., 2012). In addition to increasing demand, the desire for reduced processing costs and requirements for consistent quality and higher productivity are among the key drivers for this transition from batch to continuous in the biotechnology industry (Rathore et al., 2015).

paper.title: GMP Manufacturing and IND-Enabling Studies of a Recombinant Hyperimmune Globulin Targeting SARS-CoV-2

snippets: GIGA-2050 is the first example of a new class of drugs, recombinant polyclonal hyperimmune globulins. Prior to this work, pioneering groups have worked on manufacturing methods for much smaller mixtures of recombinant antibodies (Frandsen et al., 2011). Unlike GIGA-2050, these prior methods involved creation of separate MCBs for each mAb, followed by mixing the MCBs prior to bioproduction. For example, rozrolimupab was a mixture of 25 antibodies, whereas GIGA-2050 consists of >10,000 different antibodies. Rozrolimupab completed a Phase 2 study for treatment of primary immune thrombocytopenia (Robak et al., 2012) but has apparently been discontinued by the manufacturer. Our methods uniquely enable large-scale GMP production of mixtures of thousands of antibodies

Although this is a new class of drug, it will not require construction of new manufacturing facilities; instead, we have shown that GIGA-2050 can be manufactured using existing infrastructure already in place for manufacturing of mAbs. In 2011, the global capacity for mammalian cell production in bioreactors was approximately 0.5 million liters (Jesus et al., 2011). Capacity has continued to grow over the past decade, so should the need arise, manufacturing of a recombinant hyperimmune globulin could be scaled to produce millions of doses.

paper.title: Bioengineering of Antibody Fragments: Challenges and Opportunities

snippets:
Technologies to manufacture antibodies have had a continuous evolution over the past 50 years but there is still a need for new technologies to address challenges in selectivity, stability, higher efficacy, reduced immunogenicity and side effects in humans. Costs of production is another key element toward a new technology because it would impact therapy expenses, which in turn has a huge pharmaco-economic burden for both patients and pharmaceutical companies.

Figure 2 summarizes the challenges and opportunities that are associated with different expression platforms in regards to antibody fragment production. Expression systems are categorized into four main systems: bacterial, mammalian, plants and viral (insect cells). Bacteria expression systems are low cost capable of producing a high yield of the majority of simple proteins and peptides that are not glycosylated. Because the recombinant vector may be injected directly into the bacterial host without virus contamination by humans and bacteria, there is no requirement for any additional stage of viral eradication. Bacteria on the other hand are unable to perform posttranslational protein modifications, such as glycosylation, g-carboxylation, phosphorylation and sulfitation [127]. Proteins that are inactive but have the correct molecular structure can also be produced by bacteria, which can lead to the formation of inclusion bodies. In addition, bacteria are capable of removing signal peptides, but they are unable to degrade preproteins, such as native coagulation growth factors [127]. Endotoxins, which are produced by bacteria during the expression, are notoriously difficult to eradicate and make the purification process difficult.

sections.title: Production Challenges
sections.tldr: Large-scale manufacturing of recombinant antibodies faces numerous challenges including production variability, technical manufacturing limitations, product quality issues, and process scalability concerns that affect consistency and cost-effectiveness. (18 sources)
sections.text:
The production of recombinant antibodies at industrial scale presents a multitude of challenges that manufacturers must overcome:

- **Cell Culture and Expression Challenges**: Mammalian cell culture systems, while necessary for proper post-translational modifications, are inherently difficult to work with due to "medium complexity, serum requirement, low yield, and shear sensitivity," significantly impacting manufacturability and scalability <Paper corpusId="250600133" paperTitle="(Bourguignon et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. Expression levels remain "one of the important bottlenecks restricting the development of antibody drugs" <Paper corpusId="247223302" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

- **Process Variability and Consistency**: The sensitivity of biological production systems to environmental conditions means that "even subtle variations in the manufacturing process, such as changes in the cell culture media, pH or temperature, can lead to additional variability in the product" <Paper corpusId="52079235" paperTitle="(Melsheimer et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. Maintaining "consistency of consistent product quality" is "a huge challenge" due to the long and complex production processes <Paper corpusId="54017518" paperTitle="(Cui et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

- **Glycosylation Variability**: The "variability in the glycosylation profile of therapeutic monoclonal antibodies (mAbs), due to recombinant production technologies, leads to inconsistencies in effector functions and pharmacokinetic properties, both batch-to-batch and within single batches" <Paper corpusId="246478155" paperTitle="(Ivanova et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. While chemoenzymatic glycoengineering offers potential solutions, it faces "challenges for the industrial-scale introduction" due to "economic cost of the additional enzymatic steps and purification stages" <Paper corpusId="246478155" paperTitle="(Ivanova et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

- **Purification and Downstream Processing**: The "steady increase of product titers and the corresponding change in impurity composition represent a challenge for development and optimization of antibody production processes" <Paper corpusId="4090516" paperTitle="(Gronemeyer et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. This creates a "bottleneck" in downstream processing that requires new approaches to optimization and technology <Paper corpusId="4090516" paperTitle="(Gronemeyer et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

- **Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation**: In large-scale production, "purification intermediates are often kept at ambient temperature for brief intervals," but when liquid-liquid phase separation occurs, "the lower phases were found to be highly viscous" with viscosity remaining "exceptionally high (>100 cP) even after the solutions were warmed to room temperature" <Paper corpusId="85530569" paperTitle="(Du et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. "Mixing these highly viscous heterogeneous intermediates at large-scale and achieving solution homogeneity was time-consuming" <Paper corpusId="85530569" paperTitle="(Du et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

- **Bacterial Expression System Limitations**: For antibody fragments, "production is typically marred by low expression level and poor refolding yield" with "poor growth of cells and formation of inclusion bodies as the practical obstacles" <Paper corpusId="258062631" paperTitle="(Saroha et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. Alternative strategies like "co-expression of chaperones" or "in vitro Fab refolding from inclusion bodies" present their own problems including "enhanced proteolysis, increased soluble aggregates, growth inhibition, and lack of scalability" <Paper corpusId="258062631" paperTitle="(Saroha et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

- **Scaling Challenges for Novel Formats**: Bispecific antibodies face particular manufacturing difficulties including "protein expression problems, stability issues, or the use of non-standard approaches for manufacturing can result in poor yield or poor facility fit" <Paper corpusId="6216118" paperTitle="(Gramer et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>. Manufacturability concerns should be "evaluated and assessed early in the discovery phase" to avoid "enormous challenges to Chemistry, Manufacturing, and Control (CMC) development" <Paper corpusId="270127890" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="11225008" paperTitle="(Yang et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="253484365" paperTitle="(Zhang et al._1, 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="56484932" paperTitle="(Xu et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

- **Stability and Aggregation Issues**: During scale-up, "problems in refolding or solubility, tendencies to aggregate, and product stability at intermediate holding points can be significant issues" <Paper corpusId="80825674" paperTitle="(Aurigemma et al., 2005)" isShortName></Paper>. These challenges can lead to "subtle degradations of proteins that can lead to undesirable immunogenicity" <Paper corpusId="80825674" paperTitle="(Aurigemma et al., 2005)" isShortName></Paper>.

- **Infrastructure and Technology Adoption**: Despite proof of concepts for new technologies, "adoption of such devices in the purification process with minimal, partly due to concern associated with cost and scale-up challenges" remains limited <Paper corpusId="10327770" paperTitle="(Gupta et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. Some facilities are "more than 40-50 years old and use outdated, non-optimized technology," presenting barriers to implementing innovative approaches <Paper corpusId="18324254" paperTitle="(Jacquemart et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>.

- **Economic Considerations**: "Current production methods often require substantial capital investment, face scalability challenges, and struggle with batch-to-batch consistency" <Paper corpusId="277649345" paperTitle="(Ranbhor, 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="232482243" paperTitle="(Mahal et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. These inefficiencies affect both "production economics" and "product quality and time-to-market" <Paper corpusId="277649345" paperTitle="(Ranbhor, 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="232482243" paperTitle="(Mahal et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

paper.title: Large Area Microfluidic Bioreactor for Production of Recombinant Protein

snippets: The fact that mammalian cells are relatively difficult to work with due to factors such as medium complexity, serum requirement, low yield, and shear sensitivity has important implications in terms of manufacturability and scalability of mAbs [18]. The commercial production of mAbs and other biotherapeutic products is currently based on synthesis in 5 to 20 m 3 bioreactor tanks with mammalian cells by shaking suspension culture operated in a fed-batch or perfusion mode (Gilbert et al., 2013)(Hilal-Alnaqbi et al., 2013)(Kshirsagar et al., 2012). The commercial production of mAbs in stirred tanks faces challenges related to product and process quality, such as demands for higher productivity, glycosylation control, reproducibility, as well as other process controls (Gilbert et al., 2013)(Kshirsagar et al., 2012)(Abu-Absi et al., 2010). Most of these challenges are related to the great temporal and spatial variability of the intrinsic conditions of the fermenters. One way to improve the understanding and control of mAb production in bioreactors is to downscale the system through miniaturization in the form of microfluidic devices (Abaci et al., 2011).

paper.title: Ensuring Product Quality, Consistency and Patient Supply over Time for a Large-Volume Biologic: Experience with Remicade®

snippets:
In this summary, we review the challenges associated with manufacturing large-volume biologics and the measures needed to ensure high-quality, long-term consistency and adequate supply by presentation of the example of one of the most widely used biologics today, Remicade.

In contrast to small molecule drugs, which have defined chemical structures and are produced by predictable chemical synthesis, biologics are large molecules produced in living systems (e.g., bacteria, mammalian cells) grown in complex cell culture media. By their very nature, biologics are subject to structural variability, which may alter their properties (e.g., binding, solubility, potency and immunogenicity), and consequently their safety and efficacy in clinical practice. In general, the larger the molecule, the greater the potential variability. Monoclonal antibodies such as Remicade are among the largest, most complex biologics, containing 1300 + amino acids arranged in various subunits, with molecular weights of approximately 150,000 daltons. These antibodies undergo many post-translational modifications and consist of various isoforms containing heterogeneous glycosylation patterns. The degree of potential variability with monoclonal antibodies is considerable.

Moreover, the living systems producing biologics are sensitive to the environment. Even subtle variations in the manufacturing process, such as changes in the cell culture media, pH or temperature, can lead to additional variability in the product. Raw materials used in production, such as in drug product excipients (e.g., sucrose or polysorbate 80) and in cell culture media (e.g., trace metals), are themselves additional potential sources of variability. The manufacturer must identify, understand and measure these sources of variability and then develop a manufacturing process that can produce drug with variability kept within acceptable levels. It is essential that this process, once developed, remains stable. However, over time, it will likely be expanded or updated, which presents an additional challenge. Given the sensitivity of the biologic to its environment, the manufacturer must ensure that process changes do not alter any of its key attributes. The central challenge, therefore, to producing biologics is to do so consistently over long periods of time at an industrial scale.

snippets: Variability in the glycosylation profile of therapeutic monoclonal antibodies (mAbs), due to recombinant production technologies, leads to inconsistencies in effector functions and pharmacokinetic properties, both batch-to-batch and within single batches. The major challenges for the industrial-scale introduction of the technique stem from the need for activated sugar donors, which can participate in undesired side reactions, and from the economic cost of the additional enzymatic steps and purification stages.

paper.title: A case study of a bispecific antibody manufacturability assessment and optimization during discovery stage and its implications

snippets: Manufacturability refers to the characteristics and considerations related to large-scale production and storage. It includes optimizing expression systems, cell line development, upstream and downstream processing, formulation, stability, quality control, scalability, and cost-effectiveness. By addressing these factors, efficient and cost-effective manufacturing processes can be developed to produce high-quality BsAbs products. As an important part of developability, (Pérez et al., 2021) which refers to the likelihood that an antibody candidate will evolve into a manufacturable, stable, safe and effective drug, manufacturability should be evaluated and assessed early in the discovery phase. Ideally, potential liabilities should be identified and mitigated as early as possible (Zhang et al., 2022)(Yang et al., 2013). Antibodies with poor manufacturability will bring enormous challenges to Chemistry, Manufacturing, and Control (CMC) development, manufacturing, formulation, storage, transportation and administration, and may even lead to the failure in clinical trial (Ma et al., 2020)(Xu et al., 2019).

paper.title: Developability studies before initiation of process development

snippets: Monoclonal antibodies constitute a robust class of therapeutic proteins. Their stability, resistance to stress conditions and high solubility have allowed the successful development and commercialization of over 40 antibody-based drugs. Although mAbs enjoy a relatively high probability of success compared with other therapeutic proteins, examples of projects that are suspended due to the instability of the molecule are not uncommon. Developability assessment studies have therefore been devised to identify early during process development problems associated with stability, solubility that is insufficient to meet expected dosing or sensitivity to stress. This set of experiments includes short-term stability studies at 2−8 þC, 25 þC and 40 þC, freeze-thaw studies, limited forced degradation studies and determination of the viscosity of high concentration samples. We present here three case studies reflecting three typical outcomes: (1) no major or unexpected degradation is found and the study results are used to inform early identification of degradation pathways and potential critical quality attributes within the Quality by Design framework defined by US Food and Drug Administration guidance documents; (2) identification of specific degradation pathway(s) that do not affect potency of the molecule, with subsequent definition of proper process control and formulation strategies; and (3) identification of degradation that affects potency, resulting in program termination and reallocation of resources.

paper.title: Developability assessment at early-stage discovery to enable development of antibody-derived therapeutics

snippets: Abstract Developability refers to the likelihood that an antibody candidate will become a manufacturable, safe and efficacious drug. Although the safety and efficacy of a drug candidate will be well considered by sponsors and regulatory agencies, developability in the narrow sense can be defined as the likelihood that an antibody candidate will go smoothly through the chemistry, manufacturing and control (CMC) process at a reasonable cost and within a reasonable timeline. Developability in this sense is the focus of this review. To lower the risk that an antibody candidate with poor developability will move to the CMC stage, the candidate’s developability-related properties should be screened, assessed and optimized as early as possible. Assessment of developability at the early discovery stage should be performed in a rapid and high-throughput manner while consuming small amounts of testing materials. In addition to monoclonal antibodies, bispecific antibodies, multispecific antibodies and antibody-drug conjugates, as the derivatives of monoclonal antibodies, should also be assessed for developability. Moreover, we propose that the criterion of developability is relative: expected clinical indication, and the dosage and administration route of the antibody could affect this criterion. We also recommend a general screening process during the early discovery stage of antibody-derived therapeutics. With the advance of artificial intelligence-aided prediction of protein structures and features, computational tools can be used to predict, screen and optimize the developability of antibody candidates and greatly reduce the risk of moving a suboptimal candidate to the development stage.

paper.title: Structure, heterogeneity and developability assessment of therapeutic antibodies

snippets: ABSTRACT Increasing attention has been paid to developability assessment with the understanding that thorough evaluation of monoclonal antibody lead candidates at an early stage can avoid delays during late-stage development. The concept of developability is based on the knowledge gained from the successful development of approximately 80 marketed antibody and Fc-fusion protein drug products and from the lessons learned from many failed development programs over the last three decades. Here, we reviewed antibody quality attributes that are critical to development and traditional and state-of-the-art analytical methods to monitor those attributes. Based on our collective experiences, a practical workflow is proposed as a best practice for developability assessment including in silico evaluation, extended characterization and forced degradation using appropriate analytical methods that allow characterization with limited material consumption and fast turnaround time.

paper.title: End‐to‐end continuous bioprocessing: Impact on facility design, cost of goods, and cost of development for monoclonal antibodies

snippets: This article presents a systematic approach to evaluate the business case for continuous processing that captures trade‐offs between manufacturing and development costs for monoclonal antibodies (mAbs). A decisional tool was built that integrated cost of goods (COG) with the cost of development models and new equipment sizing equations tailored to batch, hybrid, and end‐to‐end continuous processes. The COG analysis predicted that single‐use continuous facilities (sized using a dedicated downstream processing train per bioreactor) offer more significant commercial COG savings over stainless steel batch facilities at annual demands of 100–500 kg (~35%), compared to tonnage demands of 1–3 tons (~±10%) that required multiple parallel continuous trains. Single‐use batch facilities were found to compete with continuous options on COG only at 100 kg/year. For the scenarios where batch and continuous facilities offered similar COG, the analysis identified the windows of operation required to reach different COG savings with thresholds for the perfusion rate, volumetric productivity, and media cost. When considering the project lifecycle cost, the analysis indicated that while end‐to‐end continuous facilities may struggle to compete on development costs, they become more cost‐effective than stainless steel batch facilities when considering the total out‐of‐pocket cost across both drug development and commercial activities.

sections.title: Technological Solutions and Innovations
sections.tldr: The recombinant antibody manufacturing industry has developed numerous technological solutions to address production challenges, including advanced cell engineering techniques, improved bioprocessing strategies, and novel expression systems that enhance yield and quality while reducing costs. (11 sources)
sections.text:
- **Decoupled Growth and Production Strategies**: For difficult-to-express products like bi-specific antibodies and fusion proteins, manufacturers are implementing strategies that separate cell growth from production phases. This approach allows cellular resources to be directed more efficiently toward either growth or production, improving both growth characteristics and enhancing production of challenging proteins. <Paper corpusId="235270874" paperTitle="(Donaldson et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Single-Use Bioreactors**: These systems have revolutionized manufacturing by reducing turnaround time between runs and lowering costs for both upfront investment and ongoing operational expenses. They require significantly less capital investment than traditional stainless-steel bioreactors and enable distributed manufacturing through modular platforms that can be completed within 18 months versus several years for traditional facilities. <Paper corpusId="235823004" paperTitle="(Whaley et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Continuous Bioprocessing**: The industry is gradually transitioning from batch to continuous processing, driven by increasing demand, cost reduction pressures, quality consistency requirements, and productivity needs. Integrated continuous biomanufacturing coupled with continuous chromatographic processes can reduce costs by up to 55% compared to conventional batch processing when considering both capital and operating expenses. <Paper corpusId="235823004" paperTitle="(Whaley et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="52883669" paperTitle="(Cankorur-Cetinkaya et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Advanced Media Formulation and Feeding Strategies**: Significant increases in protein production have been achieved through process improvements, particularly in media optimization, cell culture conditions, and enhanced feeding strategies. These advancements have helped boost average yields for commercial mAb production to 5-6 g/L and continue to rise. <Paper corpusId="52982930" paperTitle="(Velugula-Yellela et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>

- **CHO Cell Engineering**: Modern production improvements have been accomplished through genetic engineering of Chinese Hamster Ovary (CHO) cells and improved production line screening using high-throughput bioreactors, which allows for faster identification of high-performing cell lines. <Paper corpusId="52982930" paperTitle="(Velugula-Yellela et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Chromatography and Filtration Advancements**: Current chromatography and filtration technologies are not limiting factors up to the 10-ton scale. Long-term advances in expanded bed adsorption, simultaneous multi-column chromatography systems (SMCC), and new resins for Protein A and polishing steps offer benefits for increased plant throughput, process productivity, and facility utilization. <Paper corpusId="33331820" paperTitle="(Reichert et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Repurposing Existing Infrastructure**: For novel antibody formats like recombinant polyclonal hyperimmune globulins consisting of thousands of different antibodies, manufacturers have demonstrated that existing mAb production infrastructure can be repurposed without building new facilities. This adaptability reduces barriers to entry for new therapeutic modalities. <Paper corpusId="250712798" paperTitle="(Mizrahi et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Inducible Expression Systems**: These systems allow separation of growth and production phases in manufacturing, enabling yield optimization through controlled timing of protein expression. This approach has proven particularly valuable for transient expression systems in alternative platforms like plant-based production. <Paper corpusId="8800576" paperTitle="(Park et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Secretion-Based Expression Systems**: For antibody fragments like scFvs, secretion into culture medium enhances proper folding, prevents protein contamination, and simplifies the purification process, potentially enabling large-scale cost-effective production. This approach addresses many of the challenges associated with bacterial inclusion body formation and refolding. <Paper corpusId="14444885" paperTitle="(Cheng et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Alternative Expression Platforms**: While mammalian cells remain dominant for full antibody production due to their ability to perform post-translational modifications, bacterial systems offer advantages for simpler antibody fragments including lower cost and potentially higher yields. However, they cannot perform important modifications like glycosylation, limiting their application for full-length antibodies. <Paper corpusId="256154128" paperTitle="(Pirkalkhoran et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Chaperone Co-Expression and Refolding Strategies**: For bacterial expression of antibody fragments, approaches include co-expression of chaperones to facilitate proper folding or in vitro refolding from inclusion bodies. While these strategies face challenges including enhanced proteolysis, increased soluble aggregates, growth inhibition, and scalability issues, they represent potential solutions for cost-effective production of antibody fragments. <Paper corpusId="258062631" paperTitle="(Saroha et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Facility Modernization**: Many vaccine manufacturing facilities are 40-50 years old and use outdated, non-optimized technology. Modernizing these facilities by integrating emerging technologies proven successful in mAb manufacturing could yield significant cost reductions, though implementing such changes in older facilities presents unique challenges. <Paper corpusId="18324254" paperTitle="(Jacquemart et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>

paper.title: Decoupling Growth and Protein Production in CHO Cells: A Targeted Approach

snippets: Fed-batch cultures of Chinese Hamster Ovary cells have been used to produce high quantities of biotherapeutics, particularly monoclonal antibodies. However, a growing number of next-generation biotherapeutics, such as bi-specific antibodies and fusion proteins, are difficult to express using standard fed-batch processes. Decoupling cell growth and biotherapeutic production is becoming an increasingly desired strategy for the biomanufacturing industry, especially for difficult-to-express products. Cells are grown to a high cell density in the absence of recombinant protein production (the growth phase), then expression of the recombinant protein is induced and cell proliferation halted (the production phase), usually by combining an inducible gene expression system with a proliferation control strategy. Separating the growth and production phases allows cell resources to be more efficiently directed toward either growth or production, improving growth characteristics and enhancing the production of difficult to express proteins.

paper.title: Emerging antibody-based products for infectious diseases: Planning for metric ton manufacturing

snippets: Currently, most commercial mAbs are produced in mammalian cells (e.g. CHO, NS0) engineered to secrete large quantities of antibodies (typically in the 1-10 gram/liter range). Stainlesssteel bioreactors have historically been used for large-scale production, though single-use bioreactors have become more common in recent years due to the reduced turnaround time between manufacturing runs (clean-up operations are quicker) and reduced costs with respect to upfront investment as well as ongoing operational/maintenance expenses. Manufacturers specializing in one product generally tend to use stainlesssteel bioreactors, while single-use bioreactors are often used by contract manufacturers who produce a variety of different products. Setting up new manufacturing capacity has a significant lead time; modular platforms are being completed within 18 months while traditional fixed facilities can require several years. Multiple single-use bioreactors can be used to produce mAbs at scale and require significantly lower capital investment to construct. This technology has enabled the development of global mAb production facilities via distributed manufacturing. Integrated continuous biomanufacturing processes are also faster and cheaper and may offer more consistent processing and greater product quality. Economic analyses of continuous biomanufacturing coupled with continuous chromatographic processes (referred to as integrated continuous processing) can reduce costs by 55% compared to conventional batch processing, when both capital and operating expenses are considered.

paper.title: Bioengineering of Antibody Fragments: Challenges and Opportunities

snippets:
Technologies to manufacture antibodies have had a continuous evolution over the past 50 years but there is still a need for new technologies to address challenges in selectivity, stability, higher efficacy, reduced immunogenicity and side effects in humans. Costs of production is another key element toward a new technology because it would impact therapy expenses, which in turn has a huge pharmaco-economic burden for both patients and pharmaceutical companies.

Figure 2 summarizes the challenges and opportunities that are associated with different expression platforms in regards to antibody fragment production. Expression systems are categorized into four main systems: bacterial, mammalian, plants and viral (insect cells). Bacteria expression systems are low cost capable of producing a high yield of the majority of simple proteins and peptides that are not glycosylated. Because the recombinant vector may be injected directly into the bacterial host without virus contamination by humans and bacteria, there is no requirement for any additional stage of viral eradication. Bacteria on the other hand are unable to perform posttranslational protein modifications, such as glycosylation, g-carboxylation, phosphorylation and sulfitation [127]. Proteins that are inactive but have the correct molecular structure can also be produced by bacteria, which can lead to the formation of inclusion bodies. In addition, bacteria are capable of removing signal peptides, but they are unable to degrade preproteins, such as native coagulation growth factors [127]. Endotoxins, which are produced by bacteria during the expression, are notoriously difficult to eradicate and make the purification process difficult.

sections.title: Economic and Scaling Considerations
sections.tldr: The economics of recombinant antibody manufacturing are characterized by high capital investment requirements and pressure to reduce costs, with innovations in continuous processing and facility utilization strategies offering potential savings of up to 55%. Manufacturing capacity has expanded dramatically through both large-scale facilities and process improvements that have increased yields and reduced production costs. (11 sources)
sections.text:
The economics of large-scale recombinant antibody manufacturing present both challenges and opportunities for biopharmaceutical companies. As the monoclonal antibody market expands rapidly—projected to grow from $115.2 billion in 2018 to approximately $300 billion by 2025—manufacturers face intense pressure to reduce production costs while scaling up capacity <Paper corpusId="265464221" paperTitle="(Olin et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. This cost reduction is essential not only for remaining competitive in the growing manufacturing landscape but also for promoting broader access to these therapies through lower prices to consumers.

Traditional manufacturing approaches for recombinant antibodies often require substantial capital investment, with many companies building large-scale manufacturing plants containing multiple 10,000 L or larger cell culture bioreactors to meet growing demand <Paper corpusId="43129756" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. These facilities represent significant financial commitments, yet the industry has experienced a paradoxical development: despite growing demand, there has been an emergence of excess manufacturing capacity <Paper corpusId="25001402" paperTitle="(Kelley, 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. This surplus resulted from the parallel efforts of building large bulk manufacturing plants while simultaneously achieving dramatic improvements in cell culture processes and titers. This combination has led to a marked reduction in production costs, potentially allowing production expenses to become a relatively small fraction of the sales price for future products <Paper corpusId="25001402" paperTitle="(Kelley, 2009)" isShortName></Paper>.

For manufacturers seeking to increase capacity, two primary strategies have emerged: scaling out by building additional manufacturing facilities or intensifying production in existing plants <Paper corpusId="215407197" paperTitle="(Stepper et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Both approaches require substantial investments that must be balanced against costs and downtime during installation and subsequent re-qualification of equipment <Paper corpusId="215407197" paperTitle="(Stepper et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. For companies with established facilities, a prudent approach involves implementing intensification strategies that debottleneck production chains using available capacities and can be integrated into existing infrastructure <Paper corpusId="215407197" paperTitle="(Stepper et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="82677659" paperTitle="(Kloth et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>.

The transition toward continuous processing offers significant economic advantages, though implementation challenges remain. Economic analyses indicate that continuous manufacturing coupled with continuous chromatography systems can reduce costs substantially compared to conventional batch processing. However, fully continuous production processes may be difficult to implement in existing fed-batch facilities due to open technical and regulatory questions, including higher complexity and increased media requirements <Paper corpusId="215407197" paperTitle="(Stepper et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="30520425" paperTitle="(Langer, 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. The adoption of newer manufacturing technologies is sometimes slowed by concerns associated with cost and scale-up challenges <Paper corpusId="10327770" paperTitle="(Gupta et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>.

For downstream processing, current chromatography and filtration technologies are not considered limiting factors up to the 10-ton scale <Paper corpusId="33331820" paperTitle="(Reichert et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. Long-term advances in techniques such as expanded bed adsorption, simultaneous multi-column chromatography systems, and new resins for protein purification offer potential benefits including increased plant throughput, improved process productivity, enhanced facility utilization, and ultimately a reduction in cost of goods (COG) <Paper corpusId="33331820" paperTitle="(Reichert et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>.

The economic considerations for recombinant antibody production vary significantly by application. In diagnostic settings, there is particular pressure for less expensive rapid tests, ideally costing less than $1 <Paper corpusId="237387732" paperTitle="(Huleani et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. This drives interest in bacterial expression systems like Escherichia coli for cost-effective production of antibody fragments used in diagnostics, though these systems face their own scaling and production challenges <Paper corpusId="237387732" paperTitle="(Huleani et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

Current inefficiencies in manufacturing processes impact not only production economics but also affect product quality and time-to-market <Paper corpusId="277649345" paperTitle="(Ranbhor, 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. The industry requires innovative solutions that optimize production processes while maintaining product quality and regulatory compliance <Paper corpusId="277649345" paperTitle="(Ranbhor, 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="232482243" paperTitle="(Mahal et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. One effective approach to reduce costs involves increasing productivity in production bioreactors, which enables greater product yield without proportional increases in bioreactor resources <Paper corpusId="265464221" paperTitle="(Olin et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

paper.title: An automated high inoculation density fed‐batch bioreactor, enabled through N‐1 perfusion, accommodates clonal diversity and doubles titers

snippets: As the monoclonal antibody market valuation is ballooning rapidly, with an increase from $115.2 billion in 2018 to an expected $300 billion by 2025. 1 As the commercial pipeline of these proteins expands, a large challenge manufacturers face is dramatically reducing the cost of goods (CoGs) to remain competitive in the growing manufacturing space while also promoting democratization of therapies through reduction of cost to the customer. One effective method to reduce CoGs for biotherapeutics manufacturing is increasing the productivity in the production bioreactor, which increases total product yield without an increase in bioreactor resources.

paper.title: Cell culture processes for monoclonal antibody production

snippets: With the increasing number of protein therapeutic candidates, especially monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) entering various stages of development, biopharmaceutical companies are increasingly looking at innovative solutions to deliver this pipeline. For antibody manufacturing process development, maintaining desired quality attributes while reducing time to market, maintaining cost effectiveness, and providing manufacturing flexibility are key issues in today's competitive market, where several companies are often working on therapies for similar targets and clinical indications. Since antibody therapies may require large doses over a long period of time, manufacturing capacity becomes an issue because the drug substance must be produced in large quantities with cost and time efficiency to meet clinical requirements and pave the way toward commercialization. In response to the strong demand, many companies have built large scale manufacturing plants containing multiple 10,000 L or larger cell culture bioreactors.

paper.title: Industrialization of mAb production technology: The bioprocessing industry at a crossroads

snippets: The rapid growth in product demand for mAbs triggered parallel efforts to increase production capacity through construction of large bulk manufacturing plants as well as improvements in cell culture processes to raise product titers. This combination has led to an excess of manufacturing capacity, and together with improvements in conventional purification technologies, promises nearly unlimited production capacity in the foreseeable future. The increase in titers has also led to a marked reduction in production costs, which could then become a relatively small fraction of sales price for future products which are sold at prices at or near current levels.

paper.title: Pre-stage perfusion and ultra-high seeding cell density in CHO fed-batch culture: a case study for process intensification guided by systems biotechnology

snippets: Increasing market demands for monoclonal antibody therapeutics and the pressure for cost-reduction in their production [4,(Farid, 2007) have led to new manufacturing approaches and improved facility utilization strategies e.g., continuous production (Warikoo et al., 2012)(Pollock et al., 2013). For implementation of upcoming process intensification technologies, pharmaceutical companies can aim for scale out by building additional manufacturing capacities or for intensification in existing pharmaceutical production plants. Both strategies require substantial investments and the changes have to be balanced against cost and downtime during installation and subsequent re-qualification of equipment. In the case of fully continuous production processes, an implementation in existing fed-batch facilities is often impossible due to open technical and regulatory questions such as higher complexity and increased media amounts (Pollock et al., 2013)[8](Langer, 2014). A smart step for the development and maintenance of marketable antibody portfolios is to search for intensification strategies, which debottleneck production chains using available capacities whenever possible and which are implementable in existing facilities, such as N − 1 perfusion (Kloth et al., 2010).

paper.title: Inoculum Expansion Methods, Recombinant Mammalian Cell Lines
Continuous Bioprocessing and Perfusion: Wider Adoption Coming as Bioprocessing Matures

snippets: B atch processing has long been the predominant bioprocessing paradigm, both upand downstream. Bioprocessing f luids are processed incrementally, piped as a bolus or transferred via vessels from one process and piece of equipment to the next. This continues to work well, including a number of technological advances resulting in improvements that continue to make bioprocessing more efficient. Upstream and overall process yields are essentially doubling about every five years, with this largely driven by improved cell lines, expression systems and genetic engineering, culture media, and equipment. Among the technologies now gaining increasing adoption and market share for biopharmaceutical manufacture is continuous (bio) processing, with perfusion currently the leading technology, in terms of adoption. The use of incremental, one-step-at-a-time, classic batch processing in biopharmaceutical manufacture is different than most other major products manufacturing and high-tech industries, where processing is generally more continuous. In this context, the move toward more continuous processing in manufacturing is a common characteristic of industries starting to reach maturity. Continuous processing is exemplified by assembly lines, and petroleum refining with processing involving a rather continuous flow of the material being manufactured from one unit operation to the next. Continuous processing generally follows and eventually replaces incremental manufacturing. Continuous processing generally requires more process knowledge, equipment and technological advances than incremental manufacturing. Successful adoption of continuous processing by any industry requires each of the component processes involved to be more integrated, at least with the next process. Continuous processing requires a sufficient critical mass of technological competencies and available equipment capable of supporting process integration. For example, implementing continuous bioprocessing, such as upstream perfusion, is not practical if the next and following steps are unable to handle this output. This article reviews and details some of the key advances and trends in the bioprocessing industry that have emerged which are creating greater adoption and potential for continuous processing as the industry matures. We evaluate aspects of continuous processing, exemplified by perfusion, and the adoption of these technologies by the biopharmaceutical manufacturing (bioprocessing) industry.

Chromatography and filtration are not technology limiting up to the 10 ton scale.
